subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I’d like to talk about respect. As a
parapsychologist
I’m particularly aware of the concept of
respect because we get so
little of it, ironically.
Not from the viewers of this program, I
know.
I can talk to any parapsychologist and
they will have
stories of extreme disrespect because
the enemies of parapsychology, the
so called skeptics, like to
use the horse laugh as one of their
foremost weapons. They make it impossible for
people to have teaching positions,
research positions within universities
or other scientific establishments,
places where they might find a home,
places where they might find credibility
because they get laughed at.
People who administer
funds, foundations and government offices
are afraid to fund the field because
they’ll be laughed at.
In my work with Ted Owens, I
researched this man for ten years.
He was always going around trying to get
respect for doing good works. Healing people,
ending droughts,
using his psychokinetic powers for the
good of humanity.
You might say he was naive. He, on one
occasion, walked into the offices of the San
Francisco Chronicle, the big newspaper there and
said, “Here I am, the Great PK Man, I’m
going to end the drought.”
The guards in the
lobby just threw him out. Booted him
right out the front door. He never got to talk to an
editor. Typically when that happened
he would say, “Well, I guess I better teach
you a lesson.”
If you read my book The PK Man you will
see there were many “lessons”
involved. It got out of hand, to be honest.
After that event in San Francisco
three hundred thousand acres in California
were burned by lightning strikes, which
was one of his
trademarks - lightning strikes. I think a
thousand fires were started by lightning.
Why do I bring this up? What does
this have to do with respect?
Oddly enough it was Aleister Crowley who said,
“You should treat all people with respect
because you never know when the neighbor
next door might just be a demon.”
There is a measure of truth to that. On
one occasion, I’ve talked about it before,
I was working with Ted Owens and he had
created this
miraculous event, almost impossible to
believe but it was true. He
called me up. He was going to produce a
UFO sighting.
He was so excited, he could feel it
coming.
He said, “Jeffrey, this is going to be the
best UFO sighting on record. It will be
seen by hundreds of people. It will be
photographed. A photograph
will be published in the front page of
one of your local papers in the San
Francisco Bay area.”
Three days later the image was published
in the front page
of the Berkeley Gazette in Berkeley,
California
for an event. I’ve talked about it before.
It’s written up in The PK Man.
And this was exciting. The point I
want to make is I was on the phone with him
a couple weeks after that event. There
had been two UFO sightings,
pretty dramatic in the Bay Area, as he
had promised.
But he had promised three and there were
only two.
So I said to him, “You know Ted,
you haven’t really finished the project.
There is still another sighting that
you have to accomplish if you are going to
do everything you said you would do.”
He got angry at me.
He hung up the phone. He slammed the
phone, as a matter of fact. Within minutes
I began to feel sick. I began to get that
scratchy feeling
you get in your throat when you know
this is going to be bad. I’m getting a
serious sore throat here.
I expected I was going to have to deal with
this for a while.
But then, forty-five minutes later he called me
up and apologized.
Without specifying what had happened he
said, “Jeffrey I’m sorry.
I will never do that to you again.”
Within minutes the sore throat
lifted, which was quite a surprise to me.
I have never had that happen before.
My point is, I was able to work with Ted Owens
for ten years. He was not an easy person
to work with.
You might even describe him as one of my
friends described him as, “He was like a grizzly
bear with a burr up its ass.”
But I showed him respect. As I think
about it,
I learned to respect people that way
when I was a graduate student in
Criminology at Berkeley
doing field work at San Quentin Prison
where I conducted group
therapy sessions with murderers and
rapists. I remember the attitude of the
prison staff. One of the psychologists was supervising
me there and he said, “You know,
these inmates, they are a different kind
of cat.” That really rubbed me the wrong
way. No, they weren’t a different kind of cat.
They were human beings. Just like me. Just
like you.
That stuck with me. I realized that the
difference between
people who are serving time in prison
and people who are on the outside is not
necessarily so dramatic. I know some
of these people had committed
heinous crimes. I am not trying to excuse
their behavior. Sometimes
when I talk about how I like to embrace
the whole universe people say to me, “Well
you know, what about all the evil
that is out there?” I’m not condoning
evil by any means, not in Ted Owens, not
in the inmates I got to know in San Quentin
Prison. But I believe that in spite of anybody’s
behavior they are
entitled to respect because they are a
human being.
At base, I believe we all share the same
ground of being, ultimately. Even
like Larry Dossey writes in his book
One Mind. One consciousness.
There is one consciousness that looks
out through the eyes of every
sentient creature in the universe.
I actually believe that people who
disrespect other people,
and I get plenty of it in the comment section,
there are a number of people who are
accustomed to expressing disrespect for
others, particularly on the internet.
I think people disrespect others on the internet
much more freely than they would if they were face-to-face.
But in any case, however it’s expressed,
I think when you disrespect another
person, you are really showing disrespect for
yourself and projecting it
onto another person. So, I don’t take it
personally when people
throw shade at me. I realize they are just
expressing how they feel about
themselves. I will
tell you, I believe that is true
each and every single time.
It’s a shame because we live in a
culture where there is
so much disrespect going on.
So much. It’s sad in a way
because as I say, it means that an
awful lot of people are disrespecting
themselves.
But the first step really, to awakening
what we could call the higher mind
is to begin by respecting yourself
and respecting others. The beauty
is that, as
my friend Glenn Aparicio Parry
discussed in a recent video called
“Making America Sacred Again” that
respect is the foundation upon which
love is built. Once you find that you can
respect yourself
and respect other people, it's just
a small step to realizing actually you
love yourself
at the deep level of Self with a capital
“S.” When you discover that you love
yourself it’s just another natural step to realize
you also love all other people,
no matter what they do, say, think or feel.
You may disapprove of the things they do, say,
think or feel and still understand
that you respect and love them
at the level of being
because we all share the same ground
of being. We are all in this together,
this world.
Let me leave you with this thought.
Are there places where you don’t respect
yourself? Are you projecting in any way your own
self disrespect onto others?
Are there steps that you could take to
make amends for that and to correct it
and to begin to show respect for
every other human being, maybe even
more than that, every other living
creature, every other sentient being?
Can you do that? Is that within the realm
of possibility for you?
I’ll leave you with that thought.
Thank you
for being with me.
[Music]
